Gameplay, it's basically just Fedcom Civil War, with a small handful of extra stuff, some of which was ported from the clix universe, some of which brought over from Maxtech. Like all eras, the additional new tech was pretty reserved. They added light, snub, and heavy ppcs, MMLs, Plasma weapons, Light autocannons, AP Gauss Rifles and HAGs. Some additional stuff like XL gyros and compact heat sinks, as well as rules for industrialmechs that I don't think anyone ever used for pickup games. Basically Total Warfare covered everything Jihad when it started so any additions after BMR marked a Jihad inclusion. This also marked a period where vehicles and conventional infantry were given a fighting chance instead of being laughable stopgaps.

We also saw a bunch of Primitive mechs get introduced for the first time since the Mackie, meaning a new set of construction rules, but I think most people used them on the table in introtech/upgraded versions. Every now and again you saw Tacops gear show up, but it was usually on niche stuff like Solaris 7 mechs that you assumed nobody would field anyway, and a trickle of it showed up on 3085 units or on alternate configs.

But the transition from Jihad to Dark age era tech levels was rules whiplash like nothing before. We went from having TW being enough for almost every situation, to needing at least three rulebooks worth of equipment stupidly fast, roughly the same time as Alpha Strike was released. At the time, I suspected they were pulling Clix 2 electric boogaloo on us trying to kill the main game by drowning it in so many rules so fast that you *had* to transition to alpha strike. Until BMM was released, using dark age stuff outside of your house either meant needing a PDF-packed tablet, or bringing a library's worth of rulebooks.

Your biggest hurdles are going to be figuring out how the communication actually happens.
Morse code never really got any notable subculture IRL because it mostly functioned as a very fast letter carrier via telegram; you hand a message off to the office and the operator transmits that to a different office which notes it down and delivers it to the recipient. This is basically just snailmail but faster and restricted to words only. Outside of the telegram office, Morse code is really only useful for communicating in scenarios where you can't speak to each other; the nature of the system means it'd be less time effecient than using a properly spoken or written language.

I imagine any sort of subculture that popped up around Morse code being used for face-to-face talking would mostly revolve around being as succinct and curt as possible. Lots of slang with contextually relevant meaning developed over years and years. Certain things are referred to by acronyms that only make sense in a language that's from two countries over, effectively becoming a new word, which becomes part of a different acronym later, which then becomes slang for something totally different. It wouldn't be so much a subculture as much as it's own distinct language.

make dodging blocking and other active defenses an action and opposed check that can only be taken if you didn't take full action the previous turn. So if you moved and hit something, you're out of luck.

Attacks that get past those active defenses are still compared to the AC granted by armor, if they hit the armor apply DR based on the armor. if they don't hit the armor then the attack deals damage as normal.

if you really want to be crunchy, attacks that fail to hit the target's flat footed "dodge" aka 10+size modifier, wiff entirely because the attacker just missed outright, no action needed for the defender.
